com.versant.event
Class EventChannel

java.lang.Object
  com.versant.event.EventChannel

public class EventChannel
extends java.lang.Object

Represents a named event channel. An EventChannel object can be obtained from an EventClient using the getChannel and setChannel methods. Event channels are persistent; they are registered in the database, and continue to exist until they are explicitly deleted.

There are three types of event channels: channels for class-based events, object-based events, and query-based events. These three different types of channels are reflected in the three different types of ChannelBuilder objects: ClassChannelBuilder, ObjectChannelBuilder, and QueryChannelBuilder.

Some event types are common to all kinds of event channels. These event types are user-defined events, transaction-begin events, and transaction-end events.

See Also:
ChannelBuilder, ClassChannelBuilder, ObjectChannelBuilder, QueryChannelBuilder

Constructor.

Method Detail

addVersantEventListener

public void addVersantEventListener(VersantEventListener listener)
Receive event notifications for any events associated with this channel. If the given listener has already registered on this channel, then this request is ignored.

The events that can be delivered to a particular listener depends on the type of the event channel (class-based, object-based, or query-based), which event types the channel has registered for, and which subinterfaces of VersantEventListener (ClassEventListener, ObjectEventListener, TransactionEventListener, and UserEventListener) that the listener implements. Note that if a single listener implements multiple subinterfaces, it is only necessary to invoke the addVersantEventListener method once.

delete

public void delete()
            throws java.io.IOException
Deletes this channel, so that no events on this channel will ever be delivered to any event client. Any attempt to use the channel after it is deleted will result in a ChannelException. It is possible that a new channel with the same name is created after this channel is deleted.

Throws:
java.io.IOException

disable

public void disable()
             throws java.io.IOException
Disables this channel, so that no events on this channel will be delivered to any event client, until it is re-enabled using the enable() method. If the channel has already been disabled, then this request is ignored. If the channel has been deleted, then it throws a ChannelException. Note that any undelivered events are lost, and will not be redelivered after the channel is enabled.

Throws:
java.io.IOException

enable

public void enable()
            throws java.io.IOException
Enables a channel that has previously been disabled. If the channel was already enabled, then this request is ignored. If the channel has been deleted, then it throws a ChannelException.

Throws:
java.io.IOException

getName

public java.lang.String getName()
Returns the name of the channel.

removeVersantEventListener

public void removeVersantEventListener(VersantEventListener listener)
Removes an associated event listener from this channel. After removal, the listener will no longer be notified about events that are associated with this channel.

getListeners

public java.util.Vector getListeners()
Return the vector of Event Listeners for this channel.
